The intent is to meet the needs of the present medical civilian workforce as well as the challenges of the future workforce to meet the Army's mission.nnEstablishing the Career Program Planning Board to provide a systematic process for effective workforce and talent management.n  n  n**Why is this important to the Army?**nnArmy Career Program 53 aligns and develops the Army's Medical Civilian workforce to support the Surgeon General's strategic campaign objectives and Army Medicine Department's mission. Army commands benefit by getting access to a highly professional and competent medical force that is capable of providing sustained expeditionary health services and enabling readiness. nnArmy civilians benefit by gaining access to opportunities that help them gain and retain vital knowledge, skills, and abilities.n n n**Resources:**nn* [Army Medicine](https://www.army.mil/armymedicine) n* [Career Program 53 MilSuite page](https://www.milsuite.mil/book/groups/cp53-careerist-support)nnn**Related documents**:nn* [Career Program Management, Army Policy 690-950](https://armypubs.army.mil/epubs/DR_pubs/DR_a/pdf/web/AR690-950_Web_FINAL.pdf)n* [Army Directive 2017-13, DA Senior Enterprise Talent Management Program and Enterprise Talent Management Program](https://armypubs.army.mil/epubs/DR_pubs/DR_a/pdf/web/ARN4644_AD2017-13_Final.pdf)nn**Related STAND-TO!**: nn* [Army Senior Enterprise Talent Management Program](https://www.army.mil/standto/archive_2015-04-28)n

title: United States Army Reserve
body: #######Provided by the Office of the Chief, Army Reservenn**What is it?**nnU.S. Army Reserve is the dedicated federal reserve force of the Army. The Army Reserve generates combat ready units and Soldiers for the Army and joint services that are trained, equipped and lethal to win the nation's wars. Army Reserve Soldiers are the most diverse group in the Army and come from a wide variety of communities and backgrounds. nnThe United States Army Reserve Command is responsible for all of America's Army Reserve units. nn**What has the Army done/is doing?**nnU.S. Army Reserve played an important role in World War I and was a critical component in the war effort. During World War I, more than 670,000 Soldiers of the National Army (now known as the Reserves) served in every division of the American Expeditionary Force. nnArmy Reserve has served, fought and played a critical role during major events such as both  World Wars, Korea, Vietnam, the Persian Gulf War, overseas contingency operations and countless other crises, operations and emergencies. Throughout the history of America, the warrior citizens of the Army Reserve have and will continue to answer the nation's call. nnn**What continued efforts does the Army have planned?**nnArmy Reserve supports the operational Army and the joint services in more than 30 countries around the world, and it continues to adapt to the critical nature of combat arms on the modern battlefield. Key to this effort is Ready Force X, a readiness construct that includes more than 700 units who are ready to deploy days or weeks to fight, survive and win against emerging threats. The Army Reserve is also re-balancing its mission command structure to provide readiness oversight and essential services to Soldiers and families on a geographic basis.  n  n**Why is this important to the Army?**nnThe Army Reserve comprises nearly 20 percent of the Army's organized units, almost half its total maneuver support and a quarter of its expansion capacity during mobilization. With nearly 200,000 Soldiers spread across all 50 states, five U.S. territories and 20 time zones, America's Army Reserve is poised, positioned and ready to defend freedom on every front.  n n**Resources:**nn* [Army Reserve](http://www.usar.army.mil/)n* [USAR in WW1 (1917-1919)](http://www.usar.army.mil/WWI/)n* [Army.mil: Army Reserve News](http://www.army.mil/news/reserves/)n* [Warrior Citizen](https://www.armyreservewarriorcitizen.com)nn**Related document**:n n* [Army Reserve at a Glance](https://go.usa.gov/xPx8j)nn**Related STAND-TO!**:nn* [Multi-Component Readiness](https://www.army.mil/standto/2018-08-16)n* [Army Reserve Ambassador Program](https://www.army.mil/standto/2017-04-26)n* [Army Reserve Leadership Development](https://www.army.mil/standto/archive_2017-05-30)n* [Army Total Force Policy- Reserve Component Training Integration](https://www.army.mil/standto/archive_2014-05-21)nn**Related article**:nn* [America's Army Reserve - Yesterday and Today](http://www.usar.army.mil/News/Article/1618958/americas-army-reserve-yesterday-and-today/)nnn**Army Reserve on Social Media**:nn* [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/usarmyreserve)  n* [Twitter](https://twitter.com/USArmyReserve) @USArmyReserve n* [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/usarmyreserve/)  n* [Flickr ](https://www.flickr.com/photos/myarmyreserve)  n* [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/TheUSArmyReserve)  n

title: Sustainment, Innovation and Modernization
body: #######Provided by the Office of the Deputy Chief of Staff, G-4nn**What is it?**nnIn support of the [Army Vision](https://www.army.mil/standto/2018-06-07), the U.S. Army is innovating the way it supplies Soldiers to be faster and more efficient. Sustainment plays a large role in the Army's overall readiness. Army logisticians will continue to feed the Soldiers, fuel and arm their vehicles, helicopters, and provide critical parts on the battlefield. Sustainment, innovation and modernization will support the mission of the Army logisticians.  nn**What has the Army done/is doing?**nnAdvanced technology has given the Army predictive analytics that will assist in supplying the warfighter faster and more efficiently. The Army is developing five technologies: nn* **Autonomous resupply**: is using technology, such as artificial intelligence or robots to deliver materials autonomously or semi-autonomously by ground, air, and watercraft. n* **Additive manufacturing**:   also known as 3-D printing, produces parts from plastic and other durable materials by using 3-D printers. It has the ability to improve the performance of Army weapon systems on the battlefield. This process reduces distribution requirements, increases operational readiness, and improves materiel development. n* **Advanced power generation and distribution**: Provides greater energy output, increased fuel efficiency and management, enabling expeditionary sustainment of forces in remote areas. This could reduce the logistics footprint and extend operational reach, making Soldiers more effective and units less logistically dependent.n* **Condition-based maintenance plus**:   is a system that allows commanders to plan maintenance around their training and operational cycles to increase reliability and reduce the costs to sustain equipment.n* **Big data management**:  Allows full implementation of the Enterprise Resource Planning systems, to improve information management.  nnn**What continued efforts does the Army have planned?**nnThe Army will continue its efforts to innovate and improve the way it delivers weapons, combat vehicles, sustainment systems, and equipment needed by Soldiers. With the development of autonomous systems, artificial intelligence and robotics, Soldiers will be more effective and units less logistically dependent.n  n**Why is this important to the Army?**nnSoldiers will always be the most important asset for the Army. The [Army G-4](https://www.army.mil/info/organization/unitsandcommands/dcs/g-4), [Army Materiel Command](https://www.amc.army.mil/) and the [Army Sustainment Command](http://www.aschq.army.mil/home/default.aspx) will continue to focus on developing advanced technologies to help Soldiers do their jobs better and faster as the Army builds a more ready and lethal combat force for the future. n n**Resources:**nn* [Army G-4](https://www.army.mil/info/organization/unitsandcommands/dcs/g-4)n* [U.S. Army Materiel Command](http://www.army.mil/info/organization/unitsandcommands/commandstructure/amc/)n* [U.S. Army Sustainment Command](http://www.aschq.army.mil/home/default.aspx)n* [Army Sustainment Magazine](http://www.army.mil/armysustainment)nn**Related document**:n n* [ADP 4-0, Sustainment](https://armypubs.army.mil/epubs/DR_pubs/DR_a/pdf/web/adp4_0.pdf)nn**Related STAND-TO!**:nn* [The Army Vision](https://www.army.mil/standto/2018-06-07)n* [Additive Manufacturing]( https://www.army.mil/standto/2017-08-08)n* [Army Readiness - Common Operating Picture](https://www.army.mil/standto/2018-06-28)n* [Logistics Support Activity]( https://www.army.mil/standto/2017-05-31)n* [Logistics Readiness Centers](https://www.army.mil/standto/archive_2013-10-16)nn**Related articles**:nn* [Additive manufacturing 'big part' of Army future, AMC commander says](https://www.army.mil/article/176418/ ) n* [Improving maintenance and operations with condition based maintenance](https://www.army.mil/article/102668/)nn

title: National Preparedness Month
body: #######Provided by Office of the Deputy Chief of Staff, G-3/5/7nn**What is it?**nnNational Preparedness Month is an annual event to focus the nation's attention on the importance of taking action to prepare for potential emergencies and disasters. This year's theme is 'Disasters Happen. Prepare Now. Learn How.'  Saturday, September 15th is the National Day of Action when citizens are encouraged to participate in emergency preparedness activities such as learning about the hazards that affect their community and ways to increase self-resiliency through education and preparedness.nn**What has the Army done/is doing?**nnThe Army supports National Preparedness Month as part of its enduring culture of preparedness and resilience. To promote these concepts, the Army: nn* Maintains the [Ready Army](http://ready.army.mil/) website, a one-stop shop of useful tools and information to help Soldiers, Civilians, and Family members prepare for emergencies by encouraging Families to be informed, make a plan, build a kit and get involved.nn* Through [Department of the Army Pamphlet 525-27, Army Emergency Management Program](https://armypubs.army.mil/epubs/DR_pubs/DR_a/pdf/web/r525_27.pdf), the Army provides a comprehensive method for planning, organizing, training, equipping, and exercising the force in preparation for emergencies Soldiers may face.nn* Established a Facility Working Group to address the unique emergency preparedness needs of the Army's off-installation facilities such as recruiting stations, ROTC detachments, and Army-operated dams, locks, and similar infrastructure.nn**What continued efforts does the Army have planned?**nnThe Army is working with the American National Standards Institute to develop a Certified Army Emergency Manager credential. This initiative will create a cadre of Army Emergency Management professionals who can carry their expertise to Army commands worldwide.nnThe Army  is the executive agent for developing an improved mass warning and notification capability, and will field a system to better inform personnel of potential threats to missions, personnel, and infrastructure.nn**Why is this important to the Army?**nnThe Army needs a ready force to carry out its mission. Through participation in activities like National Preparedness Month, the Army mitigates mission risk by encouraging its Soldiers, Civilians, and Family members to be proactive in preparing for life's inevitable emergencies and disasters.n n**Resources:**nn* [Ready Army](http://ready.army.mil/) n* [Army Disaster Personnel Accountability and Assessment System (ADPAAS)]( https://adpaas.army.mil/)n* [Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA)](http://www.fema.gov/) n* [Ready Campaign](http://www.ready.gov/) n* [American Red Cross](http://www.redcross.org) n* [Citizen Corps](https://www.ready.gov/citizen-corps) n* [Family Readiness Group](http://armyfrg.org) (CAC-enabled)nn**Related document:** nn* [Department of the Army Pamphlet 525-27, Army Emergency Management Program](https://armypubs.army.mil/epubs/DR_pubs/DR_a/pdf/web/r525_27.pdf)nn**Related STAND-TO!:**nn* [America's PrepareAthon!](https://www.army.mil/standto/archive_2015-04-16) n* [Army Disaster Personnel Accountability and Assessment System](https://www.army.mil/standto/2018-08-30)nn

title: Army Disaster Personnel Accountability and Assessment System
body: #######Provided by Headquarters, Deputy Chief of Staff, Army G-1nn**What is it?**nnThe Army Disaster Personnel Accountability and Assessment System ([ADPAAS](https://adpaas.army.mil)) is the U.S. Army's method/ process of accounting for personnel and family members after catastrophes. ADPAAS is a web-based, mil-restricted, user-friendly system that enables the Army to collect accurate and timely reports in times of emergency. nnADPAAS is maintained in accordance with a variety of Federal statutes, Department of Defense and Department of the Army regulations and policies. nnn**What has the Army done/is doing?**nnADPAAS enhances the Army's ability to accept accountability reporting from Soldiers, Army Civilians and Non-Appropriated Funds (NAF) employees, overseas defense contractors, and their DEERS-eligible family members following natural or man-made disasters. nnIt enables commanders at all levels to identify and account for those in their command affected by a disaster through consolidation of self-accounting and unit mass reporting through the ADPAAS tool. nnADPAAS allows sponsors and family members affected by a catastrophe to request assistance via a Needs Assessment Survey, which in turn helps leaders prioritize the where resources and assistance is needed the most.nnn**What continued efforts does the Army have planned?**nnThe Army will continue to improve the capabilities of the ADPAAS system by implementing four major modernization lines of effort. These efforts will improve the way the Army can account for 100 percent personnel within hours during a disaster. n   n* Integration of the ALERT services, an Army owned government tool,  into ADPAAS will enable mass alert notifications to only affect individuals within a disaster zone via text, voice, and email. This will increase the Army's ability to reach its accountability goals quickly and accurately during a crisis.n* Integration of the Army organization structure data files to auto refresh the manually maintained master Unit Identification Code table in ADPAAS. This will increase efficiency by saving man-hours. n* Development of a downloadable and easy to use ADPAAS application will be fielded. This will allow affected personnel to update their ADPAAS profiles and account for themselves and their family members. This application will greatly enhance the Army NGB's National Guard Bureau's reporting abilities. n* Increase ADPAAS mobile training teams to train new ADPAAS commanding officer representatives and raise awareness of the ADPAAS program.nn n**Why is this important to the Army?**nnADPAAS is a proven and a valuable command and control readiness tool. It  increases Army preparedness, improves resiliency of America's fighting forces, supports deployed Soldiers and reassures them about the safety of their families.n n nn**Resources:**nn* [ADPAAS](https://adpaas.army.mil)n* [Army G-1: ADPAAS](http://www.armyg1.army.mil/adpaas.asp)nn**Related article:** nn* [Rebuilding Community: Army Personnel Accountability System for Disasters]( https://www.militaryonesource.mil/-/rebuilding-community-army-personnel-accountability-system-for-disasters?inheritRedirect=true)nn**Contact Information:**nn* HQDA G-1, Operations Branch, Personnel Contingency Cell: 703-697-4246 n* [Email ADPAAS Customer Support](mailto:usarmy.pentagon-e.hqda.mbx.adpaas@mail.mil)n* ADPAAS Help Desk Hotline: 1-888-276-9472n* [Email HRC Helpdesk](mailto:askhrc.army@us.army.mil)n* *Hours of operation: Monday - Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Eastern time (No longer open 24 hours.)*nn

title: Avenger Air Defense System
body: #######Provided by U.S. Army Aviation and Missile Command  nn**What is it?**nnThe Avenger Air Defense System, designated AN/TWQ-1, is a fully automated, short-range air defense system is the Army's premier shoot-on-the-move air defense weapon. It is a lightweight, highly mobile, easily transportable surface-to-air missile fire unit with eight Stinger missiles in two missile pods. It acquires, identifies, tracks and engages targets (low-flying helicopters or fixed-wing aircraft) from a stationary or moving position.nnThe Avenger, mounted on a high-mobility, multipurpose wheeled vehicle (HMMWV or Humvee), can operate in extreme weather conditions. Its infrared system, computer, communications equipment and laser range finder locate targets in daylight and at night.nnThe Avenger turret can be easily adapted to different combat vehicles, such as trucks, trailers and track vehicles, or employed as a remotely operated autonomous unit. This highly automated system rapidly and efficiently assists the gunner with target location, identification, tracking and missile lock-on. nn**What has the Army done/is doing?**nnTo address increasing national security interests to protect maneuver forces, U.S. Army Aviation and Missile Command inspected and overhauled legacy Avenger systems to build the 72 operational Avenger systems. In support of the European Command mission requirement, [Letterkenny Army Depot](https://www.letterkenny.army.mil/)'s 21 work centers were involved in overhauling and recapitalizing the Avengers. nnThe 72 Avenger systems will be shipped to Germany as a full complement for two battalions.  One battalion set will be activated and the other battalion set will be placed in prepositioned storage. nn**What continued efforts does the Army have planned?**nnThe 72 Avengers, employed by U.S. European Command, will be a  part of the [European Deterrence Initiative](https://comptroller.defense.gov/Portals/45/Documents/defbudget/fy2019/fy2019_EDI_JBook.pd) (EDI), a series of defense initiatives. These initiatives will enhance the United States' deterrence posture and improves the readiness and responsiveness of U.S. forces in Europe.n n**Why is this important to the Army?**nnThe Army must innovate and adapt concepts, equipment, and training to be ready for the next war.  An Air and Missile Defense capability, one of the six modernization priorities, ensures the Army remains the most lethal and effective land force the world has ever seen. nnAvenger Air Defense System ensures protection of Soldiers from modern and advanced air threats and missile-delivered fires, including drones.  n nn**Resources:**nn* [U.S. Army Aviation and Missile Command](https://www.army.mil/info/organization/unitsandcommands/commandstructure/amcom)n* [Letterkenny Army Depot](https://www.letterkenny.army.mil/)nnn**Related document:** nn* [European Deterrence Initiative](https://comptroller.defense.gov/Portals/45/Documents/defbudget/fy2019/fy2019_EDI_JBook.pdf)nn**Related STAND-TO!:**nn* [Assured Positioning, Navigation and Timing](https://www.army.mil/standto/2018-02-15)n* [Air and Missile Defense](https://www.army.mil/standto/2018-03-14)n* [Army Modernization](https://www.army.mil/standto/archive_2018-01-16/)n* [U.S. Army Modernization Strategy](https://www.army.mil/standto/2018-06-06)n* [Multi-Domain Battle](https://www.army.mil/standto/2017-03-08)n **U.S. Army Aviation and Missile Command on social media:**n* [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/USARMYAMCOM/)n* [Letterkenny Army Depot on Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/LetterkennyArmyDepot/)n

title: Army and Air Force Exchange Service
body: #######Provided by Army and Air Force Exchange Service nn**What is it?**nnThe Army and Air Force Exchange Service (AAFES, also referred to as The Exchange) provides quality merchandise and services to authorized shoppers to generate dividends that supplement appropriated funds in support of morale, welfare and recreation programs.nnThe Exchange operates 2,700 facilities worldwide including department stores/malls, food courts, military clothing stores, alterations shops and dry cleaners, movie theaters, gas stations and convenience stores. The Exchange is the 61st largest retailer in the United States. nnBenefits to Exchange shoppers include tax-free shopping, military-exclusive pricing and potential jobs for military family members.n nn**What has the Army done/is doing?**nnU.S. Army Installation Management Command provides review, evaluation and support for Exchange projects, facilities and services on Army installations.nnIn recent years the Army has sought to provide shopping, dining and entertainment options on installations beyond existing stores and food courts. These initiatives give Army families access to premium brand stores, free-standing restaurants, personal and health services, and entertainment venues to improve their quality-of-life. nnThe Exchange also works with the Army to provide contingency support, resources and supplies for service members involved in conflicts and natural disasters. The Exchange provides important benefits through valuable on-base destination experiences that include much more than Exchange and Express stores.  n n**What continued efforts does the Army have planned?**nnThe Exchange continues to partner with the Army to improve the quality-of-life, increase  morale and promotes readiness and resilience for Soldiers and their families. The Exchange will continue to assist in providing contingency support, resources and supplies for future conflicts and natural disasters. nnThe Exchange will continue to deploy and operate Mobile Field Exchanges in combat zones, remote areas, at military exercises, that may include partner nations, and regions affected by natural disasters, in support of Department of Defense and Army operations. nn**Why is this important to the Army?**nnThe Exchange improves military readiness and resiliency wherever Soldiers and their families serve, and 100 percent of Exchange earnings support military programs on Army and Air Force installations. Over the last 10 years, the Exchange has generated more than $2.4 billion in support for these programs at military installations worldwide.    n nn**Resources:**nn* [Exchange](https://www.aafes.com/about-exchange/)nn**Related document:** nn* [Army Regulation 215-8 / Air Force Instruction 34-211(1), Army and Air Force Exchange Service Operations](https://armypubs.army.mil/epubs/DR_pubs/DR_a/pdf/web/r215_8.pdf)nn**The Exchange on social media:**nn* [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/shopmyexchange)n* [Twitter](https://www.twitter.com/shopmyexchange)n* [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/shopmyexchange/) @shopmyexchangen

title: Army Space Training Strategy
body: #######Provided by U.S. Army Space and Missile Defense Command/Army Forces Strategic Command nn**What is it?**nnThe Army Space Training Strategy (ASTS), directed by the Army Strategic Space Plan, provides a framework to educate and train Soldiers at every level across active, guard, and reserve components -- about current space capabilities with mitigation procedures when those capabilities become contested. nn**What has the Army done/is doing?**nnU.S. Army Space and Missile Defense Command/Army Forces Strategic Command (USASMDC/ARSTRAT), is the Army's proponent for space.nn* The command, in collaboration with the U.S. Army Training and Doctrine Command (TRADOC), is tasked with integrating space training and education at the Centers of Excellence and Professional Military Education.nn* USASMDC/ARSTRAT's Space and Missile Defense School, in collaboration with TRADOC, creates an integrated range of career-long space education and training.nn* The command works with U.S. Army Forces Command to provide contested space effects for training in an operational environment, such as Combat Training Centers (CTC). The goal is to help Soldiers identify and overcome operational impacts in contested space environments.nn* The command delivers home-station training to brigade combat teams and provides subject-matter expertise to TRADOC G-2 Intelligence Directorate during exercises.nnn**What continued efforts does the Army have planned?**nnUSASMDC/ARSTRAT will continue integration efforts across three lines of effort:nn* Institutional: Review/revise doctrine, tactics, techniques and procedures; ensure appropriate levels of space content in Army Centers of Excellence functional training and education.nn* Operational: Integrate space training at home station and CTC within unit training objectives; build requirements for training devices and simulations that create realistic contested space operational environments that enable units at the soldier/system level.nn* Space Cadre Development: Assess and improve space cadre training and distribution of space billets throughout the Army.nUSASMDC/ARSTRAT will continue to work with the Program Executive Office for Simulation, Training and Instrumentation's Threat Systems Management Office to field a capability that supports a safer, more effective contested training environment.nnn**Why is this important to the Army?**nnThe Army relies on space capabilities to enable all warfighting functions. Soldiers require training to operate space-enabled systems when access to space is denied, degraded, or disrupted. Access to positioning, navigation, and timing data and communications satellites are important for effective execution of mission command and synchronization of warfighting functions. n nn**Resources:**nn* [U.S. Army Space and Missile Defense Command/Army Forces Strategic Command](http://www.army.mil/info/organization/unitsandcommands/commandstructure/smdc/)n* [Army Space Knowledge Management System](https://army.deps.mil/army/sites/ASKMS/SitePages/Home.aspx) *CAC required* nn**Related Video:** nn* [USASMDC/ARSTRAT Command Video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y4U7828PFpM)nn**Related STAND-TO!:**nn* [Assured Positioning, Navigation and Timing](https://www.army.mil/standto/archive_2018-02-15)n* [Disrupted Space Operational Environment](https://www.army.mil/standto/2018-08-07)n* [Army Space Today and in the Future](https://www.army.mil/standto/2017-11-27)n* [The Army's Dependence on Space](https://www.army.mil/standto/2017-02-23)nn**Related documents:** nn* [USASMDC/ARSTRAT Fact Sheet](http://www.smdc.army.mil/FactSheets/SMDC.pdf) n* [Trifold](http://www.smdc.army.mil/FactSheets/SMDC_trifold.pdf)n* [Joint Support Trifold](http://www.smdc.army.mil/FactSheets/Jointtrifold.pdf)n* [ASPDO Fact Sheet](http://www.smd.army.mil/FactSheets/ASPDO.pdf)n* [Operating in a denied, degraded, and disrupted Space Operational Environment](https://usacac.army.mil/sites/default/files/publications/18-28.pdf)n* [Army Space Training Integration -- D3SOE](https://atn.army.mil/space-training-integration-d3soe/army-space-training-integration-d3soe) *CAC required*n nn nn

title: Women's Equality Day
body: #######Provided by Deputy Chief of Staff, Army G-1 nn**What is it?**nnThe nation's annual observance of Women's Equality Day on August 26th commemorates the addition of the 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution in 1920, which guaranteed women the right to vote. This action marked the culmination of the long struggle by women to gain an equal voice in their government.  The women's suffrage movement in America began in 1848, when the first women's rights convention was held in Seneca Falls, New York, led by Lucretia Mott and Elizabeth Cady Stanton. nnThe 19th Amendment is a testament to the courage and tenacity of the women and men who challenged the nation to live up to its founding principles.  nnn**What has the Army done/is doing?**nnThe U.S. Army celebrates Women's Equality Day by recognizing the service of women to the nation since 1775 and who remain an invaluable and essential part of the Army. nnThe Army recognizes not only the significance of women's contributions, but also the value of diversity and inclusion. nnn**What continued efforts does the Army have planned?**nnAs the Army shapes the future force, it will ensure that every individual has the opportunity to maximize his or her potential. The military has made many strides to eliminate barriers to service, and remains committed to the idea that every American is entitled to equal treatment and opportunity. Army leaders continue to develop, foster and sustain a culture that allows women the opportunity to pursue their goals, to grow personally and professionally and to have the prospect of succeeding and prospering free from discrimination.nn**Why is this important to the Army?**nnThe Army is dedicated to ensuring equality for all of its members. Women play vital roles in the Army as Soldiers and Army Civilians and are critical members of the Army team.  Female Soldiers make up 17.4 percent of the Army and are able to serve in any military occupation as long as they qualify and meet the specific required standards. nnThe legacy of the brave women who have served, and will continue to serve in the U.S. Army further inspire Americans to strive for equality.nn n**Resources:**nn* [Army.mil: Women in the U.S. Army](https://www.army.mil/women/history?st)n* [Army G-1: Women in the Army](http://www.armyg1.army.mil/hr/wita/default.asp)n* [Army Women's Museum](http://www.awm.lee.army.mil/)n* [U.S. Army Center for Military History/Women in Army History](https://history.army.mil/html/topics/women/index.html)n nn**Related STAND-TO!:**nn* [Women's History Month](https://www.army.mil/standto/2018-03-01)n* [Army Gender Integration Implementation Plan](https://www.army.mil/standto/archive_2016-03-10)n

title: Integrated Tactical Network
body: #######Provided by Network CFT, PEO C3T and PEO Soldiernn**What is it?**nnThe Integrated Tactical Network is not a new or separate network but rather a concept that incorporates commercial network and transport capabilities with the existing tactical communications systems and networks of the Army. It focuses on a simplified, independent, mobile network solution that does not rely on a single component, to provide enhanced network availability down to the small unit dismounted leader. Integrated tactical network takes advantage of both commercial and military network transport -- to enable communications in disrupted, disconnected, intermittent and limited bandwidth environments.nnThe integrated tactical network integrates the Army's current tactical network environment (applications, devices, gateways and network transport) with commercial-off-the-shelf components and transport capabilities. nn**What has the Army done/is doing?**nnThe Army is assessing the integrated tactical network to deliver less complex and more resilient communications and connectivity to lower echelons in the brigade combat team. To achieve enhanced tactical network capabilities, initial experimentation is already underway with operational units providing feedback to augment [Army Network](https://www.army.mil/standto/2018-03-08) and Soldier systems, programs and efforts. nnThe Army is leveraging Soldier and leader feedback from joint exercises and operations to inform integrated tactical network design decisions. This model of rapid adaptation and agile procurement of technology will allow the Army to modernize with speed.nn**What continued efforts does the Army have planned?**nnThe Army is codifying a deliberate process of agile and iterative experimentation, performance testing and incorporation of Soldier feedback to identify technologies.  Throughout FY19, the Army will leverage brigade level scalability experimentation and Network Integration Evaluation 18.2. nnThe Army plans to accelerate the development of ITN requirements documents  and ensure they meet operational needs. The acquisition community, in partnership with the Network Cross-Functional Team, will continue to identify and deliver the components of the Army's integrated tactical network.nn**Why is this important to the Army?**nnThe integrated tactical network improves the warfighting capability of the Army's maneuver formations. It aligns to the Army's Network [Modernization strategy](https://www.army.mil/standto/archive_2018-06-06) and allows the Army to keep up with pace of technological change and insert capabilities as they become available to ensure the Army addresses emerging threats to maintain overmatch.n n**Resources:**nn* [PEO Soldier](http://www.peosoldier.army.mil/)n* [PEO C3T](http://peoc3t.army.mil/c3t/)nn**Related STAND-TO!:**nn* [Army Futures Command](https://www.army.mil/standto/2018-03-28)n* [U.S. Army Modernization Strategy](https://www.army.mil/standto/archive_2018-06-06)n* [Network Integration Evaluations](https://www.army.mil/standto/archive_2016-05-02)nn**U.S. Army on social media:**nn* [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/USarmy/)n* [Twitter @USArmy](https://www.twitter.com/USarmy/)n* [Instagram](http://instagram.com/usarmy/)n* [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/user/usarmy/)nn
